children.subject: I disagree. The FAANG internship will give you experience, but 1. this experience is not necessarily more than the experience of researching in a lab and 2. the experience is different than the experience needed to go to graduate school/become a good researcher. I believe that given your ability to pass the tech company interview, there will be not much more that you can gain from doing a (presumably SWE) internship compared to researching over the summer in terms of graduate school. Research requires a lot of continuity, so I would advise you to start as soon as possibleif you are dead-set on graduate school/PhD. However, if you are not, then that's a different story.

"I believe that given your ability to pass the tech company interview, there will be not much more that you can gain from doing a (presumably SWE) internship"

Not true at all lol. Some interviews are a joke..
I meant in terms of graduate school. In terms of industry/SWE there are huge amounts that can be learned in an internship.

Keeping your long-term goal in mind of getting a PhD, research is important. But a FAANG internship would arguably give you more experience and you'd learn more. Perhaps you could do the internship and do research in the Fall, or vice-versa (once you confirm with your internship that you can push it to the Fall). You have a couple summers left so you can't go wrong either way. The summer after your junior year will be very important for an internship - this is where you'll get a return offer for a full-time job. So it could be good to leave that summer open for another internship as well unless you are dead set on doing your Master's/PhD right after.
If you goal is to get PhD, then one FANG internship is enough. Most grad schools look for research experience, industry experience is a plus but research experience is critical.

history.content: Current sophomore here. Interested in getting PhD directly after Bachelor's or after MS. I interned at a FANG company last summer, and I have a return offer from the same company for this summer (2020). However, I want to start doing research next semester (I currently am not part of any lab), and I was wondering if it would be better if either a) I spend the next 2 summers doing research, or b) do research this summer and intern summer 2021. If I accept the FANG offer, I would definitely spend summer 2021 doing research.
history.subject: SWE or Research internship?
